text: The primary meaning of "radical" is not related to how popular an idea or proposal for change might be. It's not a negative or a positive term; it's descriptive. From the Latin for "root." The New Deal marked a radical change--and was hugely popular.

text: I’d agree, with a quibble. The Constitution provides for its ratification not by state legislatures—representing the sovereign states—but by the people themselves in conventions. This was deliberate. It is a compact of “We the people of the United States,” not “We the States.”
author: TerryMoran

text: Snark? Plenty of that in your initial response. My point is: You cannot understand the Founding period, and thus the original meaning of our Constitution, by reading only one side of the story, of our history. Scalia didn’t. Nor does anyone interested in the truth of the past.
author: TerryMoran

text: The creation of the presidency, of a federal taxing power, of a federal power to regulate all foreign commerce, of a federal judiciary, and the establishment of the federal Constitution as the supreme law of the land--and much more--it's all pretty huge.
author: TerryMoran

text:
And you apparently have never read a book. Start with any decent history of the ratification period. I liked this one: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003UYURJC/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&btkr=1 … 

Or just look up "George Mason." Try learning.
author: TerryMoran

text: True. But it is incorrect to call the original design at is a "state-governed republic." And none of the leading figures in the Anti-Federalist movement would have seen it that way.

text: The Constitution was designed to enhance federal power, following what most of the Framers (and the American people through their ratification) experienced as the disaster of the Articles of Confederation. This enhanced federal power was precisely what made ratification so hard.
author: TerryMoran

text: The Constitution was the greatest expansion of the power of the national government over the states in our history. That was the point. Madison even proposed a federal veto over state laws. The EC is essential, especially for a continental nation. But our history is more complex.

text: I'm all for cutting taxes. The question is: How? This bill--with all its new loopholes--actually reflects the belief that government is all-wise, that politicians can determine that some people's income is better than others, some economic choices better. Reagan this ain't.

text: Lower rates are good. Adding more loopholes and tax shelters is bad. They encourage more people to make economic decisions based on tax avoidance rather than wealth creation. Our tax code hobbles our economy with inefficient incentives. This bill makes that problem worse.
